summary: This document appears to be an excerpt from a webpage of the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, outlining its priorities regarding human trafficking and sexual exploitation of minors. It specifically cites the case of Jeffrey Epstein as an example, summarizing the charges against him, the timeframe of his alleged crimes, his method of operation, and the vacating of his indictment following his death.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Charged with sex trafficking of minors between 2002 and 2005; the indictment was vacated following his death in August 2019.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein Charged with Sex Trafficking
events.description: Prosecutors charged Jeffrey Epstein with sex trafficking of minors for acts alleged to have occurred between 2002 and 2005.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died, leading to the vacating of the indictment against him.

events.title: Alleged Sex Trafficking Period
events.description: The timeframe during which Jeffrey Epstein allegedly sexually exploited and abused dozens of underage girls, enticing them with money and using victims to recruit others.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York prioritizes cases of child pornography, enticement, endangerment, and sex trafficking.
Jeffrey Epstein was charged in July 2019 with sex trafficking of minors for alleged crimes occurring from 2002 to 2005.
Epstein's alleged method involved enticing underage girls with money for sex acts and paying some victims to recruit other minors.
The indictment against Epstein was vacated following his death in August 2019.
The document states Epstein worked with 'several employees and associates' to maintain a supply of minor victims, though none are named.
